text: Hey everybody, Ryan here and welcome back to our oral surgery series.
This video will be about implants and implant surgery.
And this is a vast topic that could involve an enormous series just by itself.
So this will just be a cursory look at implants and implant surgery, focusing again on the
high yield topics for the board exam and also for your own edification.
So why do we place implants?
Of course to replace a missing tooth.
Here is a really nice schematic showing an implant being placed into bone.
And here is a radiograph of the finished result with a restored implant crown.
Contraindications for placing an implant.
We have a list here, uncontrolled diabetes and immunocompromised patients.
These are both at higher risk of infection.
The volume and height of bone needs to be sufficient in order to support an implant.
Bisphosphonate therapy, that patient will be at risk of bisphosphonate related osteonecrosis
of the jaws or bronze.
And you may be noticing that a lot of these are contraindications for tooth extraction
as well.
And there's quite a bit of overlap between these two lists.
Bruxism, a patient who is constantly clenching and grinding their teeth may not be the best
fit for an implant.
Smoking is a relative contraindication.
Again all of these are relative contraindications.
A history of head and neck radiation.
Another familiar site from the tooth extraction contraindication list.
Patient with cleft palate.
And adolescence.
Adolescents are not done growing.
So if we place an implant in one part of the bone, as they continue to grow and their jaws
continue to grow, that implant may not be in the place that we want it to be.
So we need to wait until 20, 22, 24, until that bone is completely done growing and we
don't have to worry about that implant moving around.
Now along with age, old age is not a contraindication for placing an implant.
Just because you're older doesn't mean you can't have an implant and can't have a really
nice result with an implant.
So you may get a boards question that poses a scenario where you have an older patient
and that alone is not a contraindication for receiving an implant.
All of these are relative contraindications.
So we have three main categories of implants.
These are big picture categories.
Subperiosteal, and if we unpack this name that means under the periosteum, and it literally
rests under the periosteum layer.
And so it's not screwed into the bone at all, it's laying underneath the periosteum
just like a blanket.
And this metal framework has extensions that poke through the oral mucosa shown in pink
here for retention of a prosthesis.
So there's no true osseointegration with this implant, we'll talk about osseointegration
later in the video, and therefore has a very poor prognosis.
So it's rare to see these around at all today, and that's because most of them, if they were
placed a while ago, have since failed and they are not a great option for implant therapy.
Next we have transosteal or transosseous.
Either way you write it, that can refer to trans meaning through, and osteal meaning
the bone.
So these implants are placed through the bone.
Now these are exclusive to the mandibular anterior region because it requires an extraoral
approach.
You drill this one through the inferior border of the mandible and into the oral mucosa.
Usually they involve two to four transmandibular implants in order to support a larger framework.
Again these are very rare, it's a very involved surgery, and do not have great success either.
So that leaves us with the third category, endosteal or endosseous.
We unpack this word, it means into or in the bone.
And so the endosteal implants are placed into the bone.
Now these are available in many different forms, there is a blade shape, a ramus frame,
and the ones that are depicted here that we see by far most often.
and what we'll talk about throughout this video is the root form implant.
It's generally cylindrical and it's called a root form implant because it's shaped like a tooth root.
And so let's talk about the endosteal implant.
So an endosteal implant has four primary components if we boil it down,
and from bottom to top in the schematic we have the implant body,
the abutment, the abutment screw, and the implant crown.
So now in the next couple slides let's unpack each of these components.
So the implant body also called just the implant or the implant fixture is shown here in the top
right. It's usually axis symmetric which means if I were to draw a long axis down the center
of this implant it would be symmetric around that long axis.
The basic procedure for placing an implant such as this one is to drill a hole into the bone
and we sequentially enlarge that osteotomy which is a fancy name for the bone hole.
So we start with a smaller drill much smaller than the diameter of this implant then we go
to a larger one a larger one and finally one that's large enough to create a hole that will
support this implant being drilled into it. So the reason why we sequentially enlarge the
osteotomy is to number one reduce the amount of heat generated and this helps to keep the bone
cells alive which we desperately want and having a sharp drill and also using copious irrigation
helps with reducing heat generated as well. Secondly it helps to maintain the axis with
freehand surgery. So what the heck does that mean? Well when we're doing an implant placement we can
be using a stent or a template of sorts and we'll talk about that a little bit later or you can be
placing the implant freehanded. Now of course you have radiographs or better yet a cone beam CT
image a three basically a three-dimensional x-ray so you know how how wide the bone is how deep the
bone is and you know what angulation to place that implant at but being able to check the hole at each
step you can check how you're doing with your angulation. So you start with a really small hole
you put in a little indicator and you can say well my hole's a little bit too angled distally so next
time I when I go up to the next bigger drill I can correct that angulation. So it gives you some
opportunities to correct and maintain a proper axis. The implant body is usually inserted into
tapped holes and a tapped hole in carpentry or any trade for that matter is a hole drilled prior
to a screw being inserted. It's similar to a pilot hole except that it has the threads cut into the
inside surface of the hole. However some of these implants are self tapping and that's you can see
that by these little gouges that are made and the apical part of the implant and so they
essentially cut and create their own threads as they're drilled into the bone hole and thus do
not require this step. So that's some big-picture information about the implant body now let's talk
about the abutment. So the abutment is the part of the implant schematic here that is placed onto
you and into the implant body. So the abutment can be broken down into two big categories one
piece abutments and two piece abutments. So let's spend some time digging into the differences
between these two categories. So the one piece abutment combines the abutment and the abutment
screw into one component. So if we go back to the schematic that's combining the abutment and the
abutment screw into one big piece. So the screw is actually a part of the abutment and so the whole
thing screws into the inside of the implant body and this beautiful cross-section image here shows
that abutment adapting to the inside of the implant body and then that screw holding it in
place. So here is the implant body the abutment screw which is part of the
the larger abutment. It has no anti-rotation component which we'll talk about in a later slide.
Notice it has a smooth conical shape which is called a conus c-o-n-u-s that wedges into the
top of the implant to ensure proper seating. Now more commonly used is the two-piece abutment
and so the abutment is held to the implant body via a screw that goes down the center of both.
So in the two-piece abutment the abutment screw and the abutment are separate components and so
in the cross-section image here you can see the outside of the abutment which is here and here
interfaces with the implant body which is this part here and this part here and the screw,
the abutment screw, that drills down the center of both the abutment and the implant body.
And this is a bit difficult to comprehend but if we break it down into the four major components
of an implant hopefully that can make it a little bit easier. So this abutment does have
an anti-rotation component because you can seat it and lock it in place and then place the abutment
screw through that whole assembly. And again we'll talk more about the anti-rotation component
a little bit later and why that makes the two-piece abutment a little bit more desirable
than the one piece in most cases. And finally let's talk about the implant crown. So the
implant crown itself can be broken down into two categories the screw retained crown and a cement
retained crown. So for the screw retained crown we would place a screw through the crown into
the implant and in general the abutment and crown of this type are fabricated as one component
and then the abutment screw is placed through the entire piece into the implant. So this is
technically a now we're combining the crown and the abutment components and then the abutment
screw shown in gold here is drilled through both of them so this is technically would be an example
of a two-piece abutment where the screw and abutment are separate. Now the cons of this type
are that we have a screw access hole and so the screw access hole is typically placed in the
central fossa in the posterior teeth or in the cingulum area of the anterior teeth. Now the screw
and the access hole is very apparent and could create an aesthetic problem and what we typically
would do is place some teflon tape into the hole and then place a composite plug to fill in the
rest of the hole. So you need to position the access hole in a non-aesthetic area to avoid
even though you can match the color somewhat with composite you usually want to leave it a little
a little bit distinguishable from the implant crown in case you had to go back and
access that screw at a later time. Obviously this screw access hole can't be coming through
the facial surface of an incisor so this is why the implant has to be planned thoroughly ahead
of time to ensure proper placement and angulation of the implant so that the crown and this screw
access hole can be can be angled in a proper direction. So now the pros of this screw retain
crown one of them I already mentioned is that it can be removed at a later time all you have to do
is take out the composite plug take out the teflon tape and then you can take the screw out remove
the screw and take the crown off clean the components and do other things that are beneficial.
You have no cement to worry about with the screw retain crown which is a benefit we'll talk more
about that in just a little bit and the big one is that it takes up less vertical restorative space
than the cement retained so it's better for restricted restorative space areas.
Now the cement retained crown is where the abutment is attached as a separate component
from the crown so these two are now separate and
you can have either the one piece abutment with its own screw or the two
piece abutment with a separate screw. So like I say here the abutment is attached
separately to the implant. The pros for this one are that there's no screw access
hole so it's typically better for anterior teeth and incisors because now
we don't have to worry about having a screw access hole in an aesthetic
area that could compromise our final result. The big con is well I guess
there are two of them once it's cemented it can't be removed unless it's
physically cut off and the one I have listed here which is probably most
frequently tested is that cement may be trapped subgingivally and so if it's
trapped under the gingiva it can cause peri-implantitis. Remember that's
essentially periodontal disease around an implant instead of around a tooth so
you have the same symptoms you have gingival inflammation and bone loss and
this is a big big problem and cement a lot of research shows that cement can be
a big cause of this so that's a big negative and typically why it's
considered standard of care after placing a any implant but particularly
for cement retained implants to take a periapical radiograph or bite wing and
so you can see if there's cement that was left over and not cleaned out after
placement. Alright so those were the four components of implants now let's talk
about one piece versus two piece implants. So the one piece implant and
this is not to be confused with the one and two piece abutments the one piece
implant is where the implant body and the abutment are physically attached
together and so this whole component now we don't even have an abutment screw we
just have the abutment and the implant combined together and they're drilled
into bone as one unit. One helpful way to view the abutment
component is as the quote-unquote crown prep of this metal tooth and it's like
the metal crown prep that the implant crown will sit on to and the problem
with a one-piece implant is that you cannot correct the angle between the
two components because they're attached as one piece whereas once an implants
placed and maybe you want to correct for an angulation error you can purchase
an abutment that has a certain angle built into it and so you can correct
that post implant surgery. The two-piece implant is much more common and the
implant and the final abutment are separate components and so the final
abutment and the crown are typically placed at the same appointment usually
several weeks after the implant has been placed to allow the bone to heal and
osseointegrate which again we'll talk about a little bit later and so once the
abutment is in place the crown can either be cemented on top which is the
cement retained or the crown which includes the abutment are screwed
together into the implant which is the screw retained crown. All right let's
talk about that anti-rotation component that I mentioned before and so the
anti-rotation component can take several different forms here we see an internal
hex which is this is the top of the implant body and it has this index
that's built into the inside of the implant so that when you place an
abutment it can only go in a certain amount of ways it locks in like a lock
and key so that once the abutment is fully seated it can't spin around and
rotate and rock back and forth. Here's an external hex which shows a similar index
but this time the this hexagon is going to lock into the abutment in this
direction this way the abutment is going to lock down into the implant body
but both of these are providing the same objective to prevent rotation of the
abutment and to provide stabilization of the abutment so essentially it's
preventing spinning and preventing rocking back and forth of the abutment
and spinning and rocking are very undesirable outcomes so having this
index to lock this
various components together helps tremendously. And again, just to
recapitulate this, the anti-rotation component can only be involved with the
two-piece abutments, because the one-piece abutment has to screw down as
a conical, a uniformly conical shape, so it can afford to have this kind of
locking hex mechanism. All right, this is another thing that I mentioned before
and it's another great topic to talk about, and this is the topic of
integration. So osseointegration is a very desirable feature of titanium
implants. The great thing about titanium, and a bit more recently zirconium, is
its biocompatibility and the ability to osseointegrate with bone. So
osseointegration refers to a direct structural and functional connection
between ordered living bone and the surface of a load-bearing artificial
implant. So you usually want to check osseointegration before you place the
final abutment, and certainly the final crown, so that no mobility would be an
issue. Once an implant has properly osseointegrated, it should not be mobile
at all, because it's directly structurally and functionally connected
to that bone, so it's not going to move around. On the opposite side of the coin,
fibrous integration means that we have a presence of fibrous tissue between the
implant and the bone, so there's going to be some mobility, and this is a
failure of osseointegration, and therefore a failure of implant placement.
So along with this concept of placing the implant, we have primary and
secondary stability. Primary stability is when you first place the implant, how
well the screw threads lock into the bone that is already there. Secondary
stability refers to osseointegration. So after osseointegration occurs within a
few weeks, new bone is formed that locks into that titanium alloy. So in this
helpful graph, we start out, here's the y-axis is stability from 0 to 100%, and
the x-axis is showing weeks 1, 2, 3, 4, and so on. So we start out when we place the
implant with very good primary stability. We're just screwing like a screw into a
block of wood, we're screwing in that implant into bone. So we start with
really great primary stability, then there's some resorption occurring, and we
have a stability dip before the secondary stability takes effect. So once
we hit to around the four week mark, then we start getting osseointegration. So new
bone is forming, healing, and is locking into that titanium alloy. So
eventually that secondary stability with the new bone takes over from primary
stability and creates a successful outcome. Now you can imagine if we don't
have osseointegration and we have fibrous integration, that blue line never
happens. And then we just get more and more mobility, and that implant will be
spinning and rocking about, and it would be a failure. So we have to talk about
bone quality, because not all bone is created equal. And so in this list,
implant success rate goes from high to low. So from the type 1 bone is pictured
here on the left, this is dense cortical bone. It provides the best primary
stability, but it does have some poor secondary stability due to poor blood
supply. But that initial bone is so nice and dense and provides a great amount of
primary stability to work with. This is found in the anterior mandible region.
And then we go to type 2, which is found in the posterior mandible. Type 3 is
found in the anterior maxilla, and type 4 bone is found in the posterior maxilla.
So type 4 is soft medullary bone, has very poor primary stability, and so
if you get very poor primary stability right off the bat, you're not
going to have opportunity to create great secondary stability, even though
you might have a good blood supply. Now depending on what sources you look at,
some people might say, well type 2 and type 3 are actually the best for implant success,
because you
get a good balance of primary and secondary stability but I will say for the board exam
know that type 1 is the best type 4 is the worst in other words anterior mandible is the best place
to place an implant posterior maxilla is the worst place and I've definitely seen these questions on
the board exam absolutely so definitely know type 1 through type 4 and what regions are associated
with oh here's another great slide I would put red text on this entire slide if I could
because this is probably the most valuable information in this whole video for the board
exam where to place an implant and what numbers to remember for staying away from certain structures
and being careful where to place them so when we place an implant we want to be at least
or at minimum one millimeter away from the buccal plate the lingual plate the inferior
border of the mandible the maxillary sinus and the nasal cavity so when you place an implant
let's say it's four millimeters wide we need to make sure there's at least one millimeter of bone
buccal to that and one millimeter of bone lingual to that so in other words for a five millimeter
implant which is a little bit wider than what it should be that means with one millimeter buccal
one millimeter lingual we would need a total buccal lingual dimension a buccal lingual width
of seven millimeters so they could ask that if you have an implant diameter of three millimeters
how much buccal lingual width would you need and you need to know that you need five millimeters
and that's coming just from knowing this number from adjacent natural teeth another great question
you need at least 1.5 millimeters of space between the implant and the adjacent tooth
so this is another great question if you were placing an implant in number 30 and you had 29
and 31 to either side let's say the implant is three millimeters in diameter how much space
mesio-distally would you need and so you need to know well i need 1.5 on the distal side 1.5
on the mesial side the implant takes up three millimeters so i would need six millimeters total
things like that very simple math problems that all you need to do is recall these numbers here
we need to be two millimeters away from the inferior alveolar nerve so we need at least two
millimeters of space right here that's called the safety zone we need three millimeters of space
between adjacent implants so for away from natural teeth this is one at least 1.5 millimeters of
distance between two implants this needs to be at least three millimeters of distance might be a
little bit close in this image in this one we definitely have at least three millimeters of
space between those two implants which is good although you can see that it's right up against
the inferior alveolar nerve which is not good we need at least two millimeters of space there
and lastly we should be at least five millimeters away from the mental nerve or the mental foramen
and that's due to the anterior loop this nerve loops around before it enters the mental foramen
and so it can be deceiving because you might place the implant just anterior to the mental foramen
but you still hit the nerve because it loops around anteriorly so we have to be at least
five millimeters away from that structure so these are all really really important numbers to memorize
absolutely i can't stress enough how important this slide is to memorize
all right now that we're we're deep into the subject of surgery let's talk about
one verse two stage surgeries so one stage surgery involves placing the implant and
a healing abutment in one visit so the healing abutment or the cap the healing cap is shown here
and it sticks out of the gums essentially like an earring in an ear is the best way i can describe
it and so that helps to sculpt and mold the soft tissues around the this implant healing abutment
in order to frame the restoration appropriately so when it's time for the patient to come back
you remove this temporary healing abutment and you put in the final abutment that soft tissue
has a really nice collar and provides a great emergence profile for the implant
the two-stage surgery means that we place the implant with a cover screw
which is a thin little disc that you screw into the implant.
It's another temporary measure, but this time we're covering it up with gums.
So the healing abutment sticks out of the gums. This one is completely covered with
primary closure and
it's a two-stage surgery because the next time they come in we have to then open the gums and then place
the abutment at the next visit.
And this could be either the temporary healing abutment shown here or that final abutment that we saw in the previous slides.
So why would we do two-stage surgery? Because most patients would want to just have one surgery and be done with it.
Well, two-stage can be beneficial for
three main reasons I can think of. If you have poor primary stability,
so say we're working in the posterior maxilla, and we want to keep all occlusion off of it.
So we would place this cover screw and so we make sure that there are going to be no biting forces on the implant while
it's
healing and secondary stability is taking over.
The second reason would be if we need to place a graft,
so we'd want to close up the gums so that the bone heals properly.
The third reason is if we have a medically compromised patient, so that immunocompromised or unstable diabetes from that contraindication
slide.
So this technique would allow primary closure over the implant site which poses less infection risk.
All right, how about the impression?
So once healing is complete a final impression is made so that the crown and the abutment are properly oriented.
So we use what's called an impression coping which is used to transfer the location and angulation of the implant to a
master cast. Here is the impression coping. So you can imagine the implant has been screwed in,
maybe we did a one-stage
surgery, we took out the healing abutment, and now we're ready to take our impression. Or maybe we did a cover screw first,
now we opened that area up, and we're ready to
take an impression.
So the coping attaches into the implant in the mouth and allows you to record the angulation of
the implant, which without a set of 2D x-rays or a 3D x-ray,
we can't see the implant angulation once it's screwed in because well as you can see here
it's surrounded by gums and bones, so we can't see anything. So we screw in this impression coping which allows us to see and
which allows us to imagine where that implant is without any second guessing.
So this slide is totally beyond the scope of the board exam, but I just wanted to include this information
number one because I'm so excited about it, but number two because I know a lot of you are really curious about implants.
So the open tray impression is when you physically drill a hole in the
plastic impression tray so that you can, once the impression is seated,
you can access the coping once the material sets.
So there's a hole in the impression tray,
we might put a little piece of cotton in this little tiny screw hole here so that we can access it without
plugging in the impression material, that polyvinyl siloxane getting set into that screw hole,
so we can go back and later once the material sets,
unscrew this coping from the implant and
then there's a record of where that impression coping was so you can later seat it in that spot.
The
closed tray impression is when you take the impression like normal and then you remove the impression and
then there is a little space in
the
impression material where that impression coping was so then you later would unscrew that impression coping and then
seat it in the spot where it was on the impression.
So each technique has pros and cons and utilizes a different looking impression coping. This is an
open tray impression coping.
So once you have that impression you put a little pink stuff around the coping to block it out and
represent the gingiva called the gingival moulage.
Then you screw this thing in which is called the analog into the coping.
You pour it up like any old impression and you get a master cast where the analog
will essentially be in the exact same position
embedded in that stone of the cast as the implant is in the mouth.
So the analog provides your precise replication of the implant positioned in the mouth.
mouth. So that's a very very cursory overlook at implant impressions just to introduce some of
these concepts and terms. So socket preservation is something that we see in the oral surgery world
and this is to maintain the height and width of the alveolar ridge after a tooth extraction.
So the most important part about socket preservation is to have an atraumatic extraction.
So we're shooting for potentially a simple extraction, a non-surgical extraction. We're not
breaking off the buckle plate of the extracted tooth. We're limiting any sort of trauma to the
area and then we do a lot of the same things we do following an extraction. We irrigate that
extraction site very thoroughly, we remove granulation tissue with the curette, but then we
also place bone graft material and we like to cover that with a resorbable collagen membrane.
If you remember from the periodontic series that's some of the things that we talked about with
a guided tissue regeneration. It's a similar process we want to regenerate
the bone in that area to help fill in that socket but also to
to limit any bone loss in a buccolingual or occlusal direction. Primary closure
with this procedure is actually unnecessary.
Biologic width. This is something I have an entire video just dedicated to
the ferrule effect and biologic width, but here it's a little bit different. We're talking about
the implant being placed into bone. This surface that's contacting bone is roughened
to help with osseointegration. The smooth surface is contacting the soft tissue here,
the soft tissue collar. The gingival fibers orient next to that implant in a parallel direction.
It's parallel with the implant cuff and that's the area notated with the A here.
Gingival fibers orient next to the implant parallel with the cuff and this could be
asked on the board exam how the gingival fibers are oriented next to an implant.
The other important thing to note here is that the tooth has a periodontal ligament.
An implant does not have a periodontal ligament because it's directly contacting the alveolar bone
so without a periodontal ligament there's technically no periodontium so the implant
is unique in that matter as well. A surgical stent. I also mentioned this earlier in the video.
This is referring to guided surgery so we have a stent made we place in the patient's mouth
and this metal sleeve helps to to guide the implant drill as we're drilling the hole and
delivering the implant. The surgical stent can provide LAD for location, angulation,
and depth of placement to make sure any and all implants being placed are aligned properly
with the surgical stent so it can help in that matter.
And finally we're going to talk about implant success and implant failure and the features
that go along with each of those. So the four main characteristics of implant success are that
it's immobile and we talked about the fibrous integration having that fibrous layer in between
the implant and bone and how that's not desirable because we want that bone to be
fully osseointegrated and immobile. There should be no peri-implant radiolucency.
There should be or there will be rather some peri-implant bone loss and particularly
there's some initial bone loss that's to be expected but virtually no bone loss afterwards
so less than 0.2 millimeters per year after the first year. And then absence of symptoms
namely pain, infection, paresthesia, those sorts of things. So we should have no movement,
no radiolucency, virtually no bone loss, and no symptoms. So therefore mobility, pain, radiolucency,
and peri-implant bone loss would be all signs of implant failure. Gram-negative anaerobic rods and
filaments are often associated with implant failure, peri-implantitis, those sorts of things.
And one more
I'm sorry one more important number for the board exam 47 degrees celsius for one minute or 40
degrees celsius for seven minutes is enough to compromise osteointegration. So again this goes
back to one of those first slides I had to reduce the amount of heat generated with a sharp drill,
copious irrigation, and sequentially enlarging the osteotomy is so important because we don't
want to compromise osteointegration before even the implant is placed.
All right so that's it for this very long video. Thank you so much for watching everyone I really
hope you enjoyed learning a little bit about the fascinating world of dental implants.
